title: Swedish (1866) New Testament (Nya Testamentet)
description:
The 1866 New Testament ("Nya Testamentet") in Swedish is part of a long tradition of biblical translation in Sweden, reflecting the country's deep Christian roots and the evolution of its language. Introduced to Christianity in the 9th century, Sweden saw the creation of its first Bible translations following King Gustavus Vasa's commission in 1525. Despite the initial translation not being printed, it laid the groundwork for the first published Swedish Bible, known as ‘Gustavus Vasa’s Bible’, translated by Laurentius Petri and supported by royal patronage. This Bible, with its subsequent revisions, remains a significant part of Swedish religious and cultural heritage.

Over the centuries, efforts to revise and update the Bible's text to reflect contemporary language and understanding continued, as seen in the ‘Gustavus Adolphus Bible’ of 1617-1618 and ‘Charles XII’s Bible’ of 1702-1703. The 19th and early 20th centuries brought further revisions and translations, including the significant 1917 Bible by the Royal Commission, which has served as the standard Swedish Bible. Modern translations, like those based on J. N. Darby’s Greek text and David Hedegård’s work, demonstrate the ongoing vitality of biblical scholarship in Sweden, aiming to make the Scriptures accessible to contemporary readers.
